awd_titl_txt: Workshop: FIELD2: Exploring Issues of Culture and Inclusion in Field Experiences for Minority Students with Faculty and Administrators: Bellvue, CO - July 2020
awd_abstract_narration:
Part 1
In this workshop, issues associated with the field experience will be explored by facilitated discussion from the perspectives of faculty, station directors, and others who design and implement field-based courses, REUs, or other experiences. Participants will work together with other participants to design frameworks to address harassment and cultural bias in the field, first in a mini 4-hour-workshop in conjunction with a professional meeting where many field station directors and administrators, such as from the Ecological Society of America, are present. A smaller group of participants from the mini-workshop will be invited to a longer fall retreat designed for faculty and directors of field camps, stations, and informal experiences to address issues of inclusion and harassment. The selection process will be based on faculty who have scheduled field experiences for the 2020 spring/summer semesters. These
experiences can be formal (at a field station) or informal (such as road trips or camps). Early career faculty will be encouraged to submit field practicum ideas for consideration.

Part 2
The FIELD2 workshop will expand on the theme to specifically address the perspectives of both students and field leaders using a "Design Develop" model where participants first discuss and outline designs for diversity and bias issues in existing field experiences and then develop a curriculum for student experiences that brings diversity and inclusion stories and issues into a positive field experience. Project evaluators will also chart progress of faculty perceptions on diversity, bias and inclusion in the field sciences from the first mini-workshop through the fall retreat. The broader impacts include greater inclusion of minority students in positive field experiences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research (ICER)

por.por_cntn:
The first introduction to a field setting and working as a team in an environment outside the classroom can be a powerful motivator that encourages students to pursue STEM careers in disciplines such as ecology, geology, and other environmental science fields. Such field experiences become pivotal moments for many students; however, if that field experience is not positive and a student feels they do not belong or lack critical skills, the same experience can demotivate them potentially leading to them also leaving the discipline as a whole. Fieldwork Inspiring Expanded Leadership and Diversity (FIELD) and its associated workshop on faculty and staff administrators at the Ecological Society of America (ESA) in 2019, explored potential barriers to access and inclusion with a focus on the experience for underrepresented minority (URM) students. A combination of survey data and informal interviews of environmental science professionals and faculty at the 2019 ESA conference explored issues of implicit bias, access, power and privilege among faculty conducting field research. The different levels of knowledge among faculty on potential barriers to participation for diverse students were explored with semi-structured interviews and survey questions exploring faculty own perspectives of the skills needed to affect change for diverse students during field experiences.

DIverse students face many barriers in the environmental fields and the field experience can be a pivotal moment for many of these students. Yet the perception of the barriers to a field experience differ among those students and the administrators who guide these experiences.  Bias and the impacts on safety or feelings of inclusion were not viewed with the same understanding between administrators and students.  In addition, the location of the field experience seemed to influence those differences with student's perceptions of risk differing from the administrators. Such results suggest an important characteristic of implicit biases that can contribute to differing perceptions of safety, security and inclusion during a field experience.  This workshop and resultant surveys suggests new ways to develop replicable and scalable professional development models that can be adapted to differing institutional and regional contexts potentially leading to more inclusive field experiences for underrepresented minority students in the environmental disciplines. 

 


Last Modified: 01/28/2022
Modified by: Gillian Bowser
